instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing v-core
threads.message:
No liquid damage, Board is apple refurbished.
Fault is odd, all power rails other than v-core.
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is low. 
Fan spins up for maybe 8 seconds, spins down, spins up again and remains on permanently.
Totally lost with this one. Tried SPI rom no changes

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing v-core
threads.message:
Some rail is pulling down <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, even if all voltages are present some PGOOD line is pulling it down...... 

Remove one by one from <RESISTOR>R8164</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R8165</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R8166</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R8168</RESISTOR>, check <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> each try untill it goes up, also check <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> area...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing v-core
threads.message: <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> area was checked, i removed all resistors o ne by one but the rail didn't go back up. Considering that + the fan spinning up and down im almost certain the SMC is bad.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing v-core
threads.message: Why would the SMC be bad. <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> is still pulling down <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL>. Look at the diagram and understand how this circuit works. <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> needs 4 voltages to come in to release <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing v-core
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing v-core
threads.message: I Was poking it today, didnt really change anything, and then SYS pwrgd came high and so did V-Core, But its still not pulling the correct current, The cpu isnt getting warm. <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> is good though.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing v-core
threads.message: That is not very helpful. Probably corrosion somewhere.....but it is an Apple refurb board so expect it to be trash.
